articles.headline: Talks May End Mugabe’s Rule in Zimbabwe
articles.snippet: Opposition members said that negotiations were under way for President Robert G. Mugabe to step down, while state-run media reported that a runoff is likely.
articles.abstract: Opposition members said that negotiations were under way for President Robert G. Mugabe to step down, while state-run media reported that a runoff is likely.
articles.lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe  President Robert Mugabe’s decades-old control of Zimbabwe seemed to erode further on Tuesday, as diplomats, analysts and opposition members contended that talks were under way for the 84-year-old leader to step down after trailing in Saturday’s election.

articles.headline: Leveraged Planet
articles.snippet: The markets are global, but the decision-making isn’t. Therein lies the danger that transcends borders.
articles.abstract: The markets are global, but the decision-making isn’t. Therein lies the danger that transcends borders.
articles.lead_paragraph: JUST before JPMorgan Chase announced its initial $2-a-share deal to buy Bear Stearns, Ben Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, held an extraordinary impromptu conference call. The participants on the Sunday night call, who got a preview of the deal, were Wall Street’s biggest power brokers: Lloyd Blankfein of Goldman Sachs dialed in from home. John Mack of Morgan Stanley rushed to the office to listen on speakerphone. Richard Fuld of Lehman Brothers, who had been directed to return home from a business trip in New Delhi by none other than Henry Paulson, the Treasury secretary, was patched in, too, among others.

articles.headline: Wall Street Shows Optimism That Crisis Is Fading
articles.snippet: Stocks started the second quarter with a soaring rally, as investors found reasons to believe that the drumbeat of subprime woes may be coming to an end.
articles.abstract: Stocks started the second quarter with a soaring rally, as investors found reasons to believe that the drumbeat of subprime woes may be coming to an end.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stocks started the second quarter with a soaring rally on Tuesday that sent the Dow Jones industrial average up nearly 400 points, its best performance in two weeks, as investors found reasons to take heart in a fresh round of mortgage-related write-offs at UBS and Deutsche Bank and a capital infusion at Lehman Brothers, the brokerage firm.

articles.headline: Playing the Housing Blame Game
articles.snippet: The people who created the current tax code — in the White House and in Congress, both Democrat and Republican — bear responsibility, too.
articles.abstract: The people who created the current tax code — in the White House and in Congress, both Democrat and Republican — bear responsibility, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: In late 2005, when a panel of tax experts appointed by President Bush came out with a plan to overhaul the tax code, my editors assigned me to see how it might affect the housing market. My first call was to David Rosenbaum, a Washington correspondent for The Times who was writing the main article about the plan.

articles.headline: To See a Stock Market Bubble Bursting, Look at Shanghai
articles.snippet: After two years of soaring share prices, the Shanghai composite index has plunged 45 percent from its high, reached last October.
articles.abstract: After two years of soaring share prices, the Shanghai composite index has plunged 45 percent from its high, reached last October.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  A year ago, investors like Guan Ling were ebullient. Chinese share prices had climbed over 500 percent in the span of two years, setting off a nationwide stock buying frenzy.

articles.headline: UBS to Write Down Another $19 Billion
articles.snippet: The Swiss bank, which also announced the resignation of its chairman, said the write-down would result in a $12 billion quarterly loss.
articles.abstract: The Swiss bank, which also announced the resignation of its chairman, said the write-down would result in a $12 billion quarterly loss.
articles.lead_paragraph: The mortgage crisis set off fresh shock waves Tuesday, with the biggest banks in Switzerland and Germany announcing huge write-downs totaling $23 billion, adding to the hundreds of billions in losses that financial firms already face from the subprime mortgage fallout.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Julia Werdigier

articles.headline: To Court or Shun the Wealth of Nations
articles.snippet: Many Wall Street executives are concerned that increased scrutiny on sovereign funds runs the risk of driving away the world’s largest pool of capital just when the United States economy needs it most.
articles.abstract: Many Wall Street executives are concerned that increased scrutiny on sovereign funds runs the risk of driving away the world’s largest pool of capital just when the United States economy needs it most.
articles.lead_paragraph: A PROMINENT American financier, weary from weeks on the money trail that leads through Abu Dhabi, Riyadh, Doha and Dubai, called in recently with these impressions from the road: “They are scratching their heads, they don’t want to be underappreciated or made a fool of,” he said of the executives managing more than $1 trillion in sovereign and central bank funds.

articles.headline: A Bipartisan Bid on Mortgage Aid Is Gaining Speed
articles.snippet: The push is the latest sign of a growing consensus that broader government action is needed to prevent a torrent of new foreclosures.
articles.abstract: The push is the latest sign of a growing consensus that broader government action is needed to prevent a torrent of new foreclosures.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Casting aside partisan differences, Senate Democratic and Republican leaders said on Tuesday that they would work urgently on a package of legislation to help millions of homeowners at risk of foreclosure, with the hope of bringing a bill to the floor as early as Wednesday afternoon.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: Bernanke Faces Bear Stearns Queries
articles.snippet: At Congressional hearings this week, Ben S. Bernanke will be asked to explain how and why the Fed has taken such extraordinary actions to curb a financial crisis.
articles.abstract: At Congressional hearings this week, Ben S. Bernanke will be asked to explain how and why the Fed has taken such extraordinary actions to curb a financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Long before taking office as chairman of the Federal Reserve, Ben S. Bernanke wrote an article with some other academics calling for the Fed to demystify its actions and pronouncements.
